(MISCONCEPTION) Incorrect build-up method: using a multiplicative strategy on non-integer ratios and then using a constant difference strategy to handle the remainder
(MISCONCEPTION) Magical halving/doubling: doubling/halving one of the numbers in the problem in order to find an answer

(MISCONCEPTION) Constant sum: find the sum of the two parts of a ratio and assume the sum of the other ratio is the same and solve backwards (e.g., to solve 3/6 : 7/x, a student might think "3+6=9, so 7+x=9. X=2")
(MISCONCEPTION) Comparing only the value of the numerator between two ratios without attending to the value of the denominator
(MISCONCEPTION) Inappropriate centrations: there is no obvious application of ratio/rate and instead, the learner focuses on one measure of the ratio/rate
